metadata.title: Synthesis and characterization of a novel hydride polymer P-DSBT/ZnO nano-composite for optoelectronic applications

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Molecular Liquids
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /mol l iq
Synthesis and characterization of a novel hydride polymer P-DSBT/ZnO nano-composite for optoelectronic applications
Mehdi Akermi a,b,⁎, Nejmeddine Jaballah b, Ibrahim M. Alarifi c,⁎, Mohammad Rahimi-Gorji d,e, Rafik Ben Chaabane b, Hafedh Ben Ouada b, Mustapha Majdoub b
a Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, Jazan University, Jazan, Saudi Arabia b Laboratory of Interfaces and Advanced Materials, University of Monastir, Faculty of Science, Boulevard of the Environment, 5019 Monastir, Tunisia c Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, College of Engineering, Majmaah University, Al-Majmaah 11952, Saudi Arabia d Experimental Surgery Lab, Faculty of Medicine and Health Science, Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium e Biofluid, Tissue and Solid Mechanics for Medical Applications Lab (IBiTech-bioMMeda), Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium
⁎ Corresponding authors at: Department of Physics, Fac Jazan, Saudi Arabia and Department of Mechanical and In Engineering, Majmaah University, Al-Majmaah 11952, Sa
E-mail addresses: makermi@jazanu.edu.sa (M. Akerm (I.M. Alarifi), mohammad.rahimigorji@ugent.be, m69.rahi (M. Rahimi-Gorji).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2019.110963 0167-7322/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 28 March 2019 Received in revised form 2 May 2019 Accepted 11 May 2019 Available online 15 May 2019
This paper presents the effect of nanoparticle concentration on the performance of hybrid polymer (P-DSBT)/Zinc Oxide (ZnO) thin layers. For studying themorphology, the structure and the optical behavior of the different synthesizednanocomposites, FTIR transmission spectra, scanning electronmicroscopy (SEM), Transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray diffractometry (XRD)were used to characterize ZnO nanostructures, atomic forcemicroscopy, UV–Vis absorption, photoluminescence spectroscopies and contact anglemeasurement were used to characterize (P-DSBT)/Zinc Oxide (ZnO) nanocomposites. It has been shown that the RMS (Root Mean Square) roughness of the hybrid layers increases as a function of the percentages of ZnO in the matrix. A clear participation of nanoparticles in the nanocomposites absorption has been demonstrated inUV–Vis spectrawithmaintaining the absorption features of the polymer. A photoluminescence study at room temperature was been also carried out under optical excitation set as λ= 375 nm. It was confirmed that when increasing the ZnO concentration in the polymer, a shift towards red was observed and the contact angle of the composite layers decreases progressively comparing with the pure polymer. Interestingly, this confirms that polymer and polymer–ZnO hybrid nanocomposites are well adherent to the contaminated free solid surface.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: P-DSBT polymer Zinc oxide (ZnO) Nanocomposite Oxide semiconductor (OS) Optical characterization

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, organic–inorganic hybrid nanocomposite materials have been regarded as new generation of high performance materials because of their unique properties emerging from the combination of organic and inorganic hybrid materials. They have the synergism between the outstanding characteristics of inorganic nano-fillers (rigidity, excellent thermal stability and high mechanical strength) with those of organic polymers (low weight, flexibility, and good processability) [1–2]. Generally, the resultant nanocomposites display enhanced optical, thermal, mechanical, magnetic and optoelectronic properties [3–17]. Therefore, the composites have been widely used in the various fields such as safety, protective garments, automotive, aerospace, electronics and optical devices [18]. Next generation Oxide Semiconductors
ulty of Science, Jazan University, dustrial Engineering, College of udi Arabia. i), i.alarifi@mu.edu.sa mi@yahoo.com
(OS) can be formed as the integration, with a controlled manner, of nanoparticles into amatrix of a polymer solution [19]. Polymer incorporated metal oxide based hybrid materials are emerging as a potential candidate for optoelectronic applications [20]. Studies on optoelectronic revealed that ultra-fast photo induced charge transfer can also occur between a conjugated polymer and ametal oxide semiconductor [21] such as TiO2, ZnO, SnO2 …etc. These nanocomposites show interesting properties compared to the individual material. Among them, zinc oxide (ZnO) forms versatile materials used in different fields for applications such as solar cells, optical waveguides and gas sensors [22,23]. These materials have interesting properties such as the high chemical stability and non-toxicity, as well as various morphologies (nanowire, [24] nanobelt, [25] nanoplate, [26] nanotube, [27]), rendering them suitable for nanodevice design. ZnO is a II–VI-semiconductor with a large band gap of approximately 3.34 eV [28]. It crystallizes in a hexagonal wurtzite structure [29,30]. Its crystal growth is strongly influenced by external conditions such as reaction temperature, pH of the solution and the nature of additives [31,32]. The properties of ZnO structure consequently depend strongly on the synthesis method and conditions [33–35]. In the present work, a novel organic/inorganic hybrid nanocomposite was synthesized. This novel hybrid nanocomposite comprises new
sulfur-containing polymer based on the distyrylbithiophene πconjugated system and ZnO which forms the organic and the inorganic material, respectively. The organicmaterial and inorganicmaterials was synthesized by theWittig poly-condensation technique and by thermal decomposition of zinc hydroxide [36–38], respectively. The ZnO nanoparticles are added to the distyrylbithiophenematrix in differentweight percentages ranging from 10 to 100% and hybrid nanocomposite layers were prepared by spin casting on Indium Tin Oxide (ITO) substrate. The compositional analysis was carried out by UV–vis and photoluminescence. The interaction between distyrylbithiophene and ZnO was investigated by atomic force microscopy (AFM) and contact angle measurement.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of the P-DSBT polymer
sections.text: The sulfur-containing polymer (P-DSBT, Fig. 1) was synthesized via the witting polycondensation [39].To a stirred equimolar mixture of 1,1′‑thiobis (4‑ethoxy‑3‑triphenylphosphoniomethylbenzene) dichloride (1 mmol) and ‑′5,50 diformyl‑2,2′‑bithiophene (1 mmol) in 10 mL of anhydrous THF, 10 mL of a 0.5 M t-BuOK solution in THF(5 mmol) was addeddropwise at roomtemperature under an argon atmosphere. The reaction mixture was stirred for 24 h after the addition and then acidified with 3% aqueous hydrochloric acid, poured into water, and extracted with chloroform. The organic phase was washed with water, concentrated, and then precipitated inmethanol. Further purification of the polymer was carried out by several precipitations in methanol from chloroform solution.

sections.heading: 3. Synthesis of zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles
sections.text:
The synthesis of zinc oxide nanostructureswas carried out using zinc acetate dehydrate and sodium hydroxide as precursors. An aqueous solution of zinc acetate (0.2 M) was prepared. The solution pH was adjusted to 9.5 by adding Sodium hydroxide (NaOH). After reaching pH9.5 the colloidal solution was left stirring for 2 h, then white precipitate was separated by centrifugation at a speed of 3000 rpm for 20 min at room temperature. Several extractions,washingwithwater and ethanol were performed after every centrifugation to remove sodium acetate. Finally, the powderswere annealed at 310 °C for 10 h [40]. The transformation of equivalent volume of zinc acetate and sodium hydroxide into the ZnO crystals was accomplished through simple reactions as follows:
ages of nanostructure ZnO.

sections.heading: 4. Synthesis of P-DSBT/ZnO hybrid nanocomposites
sections.text:
Mechanical mixing method was employed for preparation of PDSBT/ZnO hybrid nanocomposites. Nano-crystalline ZnO powder was added to P-DSBT matrix in different weight percentages scaling from 10 to 100% wt. The obtained powder was dissolved in a chloroformed solvent and stirred for 2 h with the help of magnetic stirrer to obtain a sulfur-containing P-DSBT/ZnO hybrid casting solution. The resultant casting solution was used for the preparation of sulfur-containing P-
DSBT/ZnO hybrid nanocomposites layers. Then, these layers were deposited on a 10 × 10mm2 Indium tin oxide (ITO) substrate using a simple and cost effective spin-coating technique. Finally, thin

P-DSBT/ZnO layers were elaborated in different percentages and characterized by different characterization techniques to investigate on the sample surface topography and its wettability property.

sections.heading: 5.1. FTIR spectroscopy
sections.text: Fig. 2 shows the nanostructure IR spectrum (ZnO powders) which was acquired in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 for the powders calcined at 300 °C. Absorption bands near 3500 cm–1 represent O\\Hmode of vibration, those at 2938 cm−1 are C\\H stretching mode and those at 1400–1600 cm−1 are the C_O stretching mode. The band arising from the absorption of atmospheric CO2 on the metallic cations at 2350 cm−1 and bonding between Zn\\O (400 cm−1, 550 cm−1) are also visible [41].

sections.heading: 5.2. Analysis by X-ray diffraction
sections.text:
The crystal structure of ZnO nanoparticules was characterized by Xray diffractometer equipped with a monochromated CuKa (l 1/4 1:54249 A) radiation. Nanoparticules (XRD) patterns recorded from 28 to 71 in 2θ are shown in Fig. 3. All peaks present in the diffractograms have been indexed according to the Hexagonal wurtzite structure of ZnO. Thus, we can conclude that the powders obtained are well crystallized. The thermodynamically stable phase for ZnO is thewurtzite structure in the hexagonal crystal system, although two other metastable cubic phases may exist as well, namely zinc blende and high pressure rock-salt. In Ref. [42], the quartzite crystal structure features noncentrosymmetric symmetry and polar surfaces and is best described as alternatingplanes composed of tetrahedral coordinated Zn2+ andO2– ions stacked along the c axis. The main significant peaks for ZnO film were found to be (100), (002), (101), (102) and (110), (103), (200), (112) and (201) [43]. The crystalline size was evaluated from the XRD
data. The width of the Bragg peak is a combination of both instrument-and sample-dependent effects. In order to dissociate these contributions, we collected a diffraction pattern from the line broadening of a standardmaterial, silicon, to determine the instrumental broadening [44]. The corrected instrumental broadening βSi= 0.073 rad; βhkl corresponding to the diffraction peak of ZnO was estimated by using Eq. (1) [45]:
βhkl ¼ βhklð Þ2measured− β2instrumetale h i1 2 ð3Þ
The crystallite size of the ZnOwas determined from βhkl of (101) diffraction peak using the Scherrer formula:
D ¼ 0:94λ βhklcosθ
ð4Þ
where D, λ, θ and β are the mean grain size, the X-ray wavelength and the Bragg diffraction angle of the (101) peak, respectively. The XRD pattern of the sample indicates enhanced intensity for the peak corresponding to (101) plane, indicating preferential orientation along the c-axis. The crystallite size was found to be (36 ± 0.23) nm.
Fig. 4a and b shows the representative SEM and TEM images of the obtained ZnO material. In both figures, quite characteristic morphologies of the as-synthesized ZnO structures are observed. We can observe that the aggregates of ZnO nanoparticles of spherical shape of dimension of ten nanometers.

sections.heading: 5.3. AFM analysis
sections.text: The two-dimensional (2D) surface topography of P-DSBT/ZnO (10–100%) hybrid nanocomposite was investigated using atomic force microscopy (AFM). Fig. 5 shows the AFM images in scanning mode of the pure polymer (Fig. 5a) and the

P-DSBT/ZnO hybrid layers deposited on an ITO substrate (Fig. 5b, c, d, e, and f). Obtained AFM images, clearly state that there is a significant difference between the observed layers; the more ZnO concentration was incorporated in the P-DSBT/ZnO hybrid films, the better nanoparticles dispersion will be (Fig. 5b and c). Furthermore, for higher ZnO concentrations (40, 50 and 100%), nanoparticles aggregates embedded in the matrix was clearly observed (Fig. 5d, e, and f). Table 1 summarizes the obtained RMS roughness values corresponding to 5 different incorporated ZnO mass ratios (10, 20, 40, 50 and 100%).
The RMS roughness of the hybrid P-DSBT/ZnO layers increases as a function of the ZnO concentration incorporated in the polymer P-DSBT material, following a Boltzmann equation as:
RMS ¼ aþ b−a

where (a) and (b) are empirical fixed value parameters and CZnO0 and CZnO are the critical (set as 49%) and the used ZnO mass ratios, respectively. Fig. 6 shows this dependency and it is clear that the roughness of P-DSBT/ZnO hybrid material begins to increase and becomes greater than the roughness of pure P-DSBT layers when the mass ratio of ZnO nanoparticles exceeds a critical value fixed at 49%. Moreover, the obtained AFM images reported that a 5 nm2 area can be considered as smooth and exhibits spherical elongated structures with disconnected
channels which indicates an increase in the material surface roughness as confirmed by Rossen Sedev [45].

sections.heading: 5.4. Contact angle measurement
sections.text:
The contact angle measurement is a useful technique for testing the surface wettability property of solid surface with liquid surface, which forms a liquid droplet on interface of three media air, water and film surface. The contact angle depends on three major factors; i.e. the surface roughness, the homogeneity and the chemical composition of the studied material. In fact, a contact angle greater (lower) than 90° indicates low (high) wettability and a hydrophobic (hydrophilic) surface and vice versa. For each hybrid film, three different reference liquids were used; deionized water, formamide and diiodomethane. Using the Van Oss model, surface energy (γs) can be calculated knowing the polar and acid-base components (γ+, γ−) and the surface energy dispersive (γd, γp) following Eq. (6) as:
γS ¼ γdS þ γpS ¼ γdS þ 2 γþS ∙γ−S 1 2 ð6Þ
Table 2 gives the measured contact angles Ө°water, Ө°form and Ө°diio for these liquids; i.e. deionized water, formamide and diiodomethane, respectively and the corresponding surface energies (γs).
The values of the surface energies of the thin layers as well as their dispersive andno-dispersive componentswere deduced frommeasurement by taking the mean angles of the liquid/solid equilibria and using
rgy of the surface (γs) of composite films as a function of different quantities of ZnO (b).
the Owens-Wendt geometric mean method [46]. Fig. 7 shows that the contact angle of the composite films decreases progressively with increasing the ZnO concentration in the P-DSBT polymer comparing to the pure polymer material. This implies that P-DSBT and P-DSBT/ZnO hybrid nanocomposites are well adherent to the contaminated free solid surface. It is also known that the hydrophilic nature is an essential factor for sensing applications [47]. The P-DSBT/ZnO layer has a greater roughness, which can considerably increase the solid-liquid interfacial zone [48,49]. These findings can be explained by the fact that composites are rich in oxygen which has a low surface free energy and thus can considerably increase the contact angle of the water by H+ ion interaction with oxygen atoms in the surface. In the other hand, γ−
energy can predict the material surface alkalinity nature [50]. Fig. 8a shows that surface energy (γs) increases with increasing incorporated ZnOmass ratio. This can be explained by the fact that ZnO nanoparticles interact with the polymer chain's layout on the ITO substrate (Fig. 8b).

sections.heading: 5.5. Uv–visible spectroscopy study
sections.text:
To understand the effect of addition of ZnO nanoparticles in P-DSBT matrix the Uv–vis spectroscopy was carried out. Fig. 9a shows the UV– vis spectra of P-DSBT and P-DSBT–ZnO (50%) hybrid nanocomposites. P-DSBT film shows broad absorption peak at 432 nm which is in good agreement with reported. The P-DSBT/ZnO hybrid film whose
maximum absorption band is located at 445 nm therefore exhibits a red shift with respect to the pure P-DSBT film. This shift is associated by the effect of ZnO nanoparticles which have a lower optical gap [51]. The shift was observed for all nanocomposite films.
The amount of visible radiation absorbed by the polymer alone is higher than that of the other hybrid devices (P-DSBT/ZnO). Fig. 9b shows the absorbance in the visible of the various percentages of ZnO in the P-DSBT decreases and from 40% increases and this improvement in absorbance is explained by the formation of ZnO aggregates. Indeed, the more the concentration of ZnO increases, the number of photons absorbed decreases [51].

sections.heading: 5.6. Determination of optical band gap
sections.text:
Optical transition in the nanocomposite films was estimated using Tauc's plot. The frequency dependent relation of the absorption coefficient has been shown by the following relation:
αhνð Þ1=n ¼ k hν−Egð Þ ð7Þ
where -absorption coefficient, h-photon energy n-nature of electronic transition, K-proportionality constant and Egoptical band gap are reflected. The absorption coefficient has been calculated using Beer's Lambert law as shown by the following relation [52].
α ¼ − 1=dð Þ ln Tð Þ ð8Þ
where, d - thickness and T - transmittance of the film. Fig. 10 showed direct allowed transition between the edge of valance band and conduction band of pristine polymer P-DSBT and P-DSBT/ZnO nanocomposites. The optical band gap was obtained by extrapolation of the linear region of corresponding curve between (αhν)2 and hν. The optical band gap of P-DSBT was estimated ~2.41 respectively. It was observed that there was major change in PANI/PPY/ZnO nanocomposites due to incorporation of the ZnO nanoparticle. With increase in the concentration of ZnO into P-DSBT polymeric pattern, the optical band gap decreased due to the formation of intermediate level in between energy gap and led to increase p-type conductivity. Therefore, electron startedmoving from valance band to conduction band through intermediate level. As a consequence, the conductivity was increased and the band gap was decreased. The optimized band gap (~2.36 eV) was observed for 40% P-DSBT/ZnO nanocomposite.

sections.heading: 5.7.1. Static study
sections.text: Aphotoluminescence study at room temperaturewas carried out for the pure P-DSBT and the hydride P-DSBT/ZnO material for different incorporated ZnO mass ratios (20, 40, 50, and 100%) in the polymer matrix (Fig. 10). The illustrated spectra corresponds to wavelength range scaling from 600 to 800 nm and under optical excitation λ = 375 nm. Fig. 11 shows a clear shift of the luminescence peak towards red when increasing the ZnO nanoparticle concentration. This shift is related to the occurred changes in the conjugation lengths [53] due to the incorporation if the ZnOnanoparticles. The energy decrease is essentially due to the aggregate formation which was confirmed by AFM images. In fact, integrating more ZnO nanoparticle has the effect of stretching the agglomeration regions and further separation of the polymer chains. Hence, the polymer becomes less conjugate.

sections.heading: 5.7.2. Dynamic study
sections.text:
Fig. 12 shows the photoluminescence resolved in time. The time decay can be simulated by a single exponential function of the form: I (t) = Ae(−t/τ) where A is the corresponding amplitude at t = 0 and τ is the duration of life level of the excited state. The exponential component decreases with τ which increases with the concentration of ZnO present in the P-DSBT matrix (Fig. 11a). The time resolution showed that the lifetime of charge carriers increases as a function of the concentration of ZnO, scaling from 708 ps for the pure P-DSBT polymer to 805 ps for 40% of incorporated ZnO mass ratio (before the formation of the aggregates). Fig. 11b can be attributed to an accentuated diffusion of the electronic excitations of the polymer to ZnO nanocrystals [54].

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: Nanoparticles of ZnO were incorporated to P-DSBT polymer matrix in different weight percentages (10–100% wt) and the hybrid material was successfully placed on an ITO substrate using a spin coating technique. Atomic forcemicroscopy (AFM) showed that P-DSBT/ZnO hybrid nanocomposite samples prepared by 10, 20 and 40%mass ratio reveal a good dispersion of ZnOnanoparticles over the polymer and high surface area. Samples prepared with higher ZnO mass ratios (50 and 100%) show the formation of aggregates. These findings are interesting in next generation optoelectronic devices and gas sensing devices.

sections.text: The authors extend their appreciation to the Deanship of Scientific Research at Majmaah University for funding this work under Project Number RGP-2019-16.
